soil_mix: Miracle-Gro Mulch, Miracle-Gro Potting Mix, Soil/Sand
origin_history: Direct-sown in the center of the Raised Bed at Stake 3.
Compacted topsoil/sand layer partially removed on Dec 9, 2025.
Replaced with Miracle-Gro Potting Mix to improve aeration.
whats_been_logged: The plant is now operating in sustained fruiting mode, producing multiple female flowers while an established fruit continues to enlarge. Growth patterns reflect active reproductive cycling, with increasing demand for consistent moisture, successful pollination timing, and structural preparation for vertical training as fruit load builds.
current_state: The plant displays a vigorous, open canopy with thick petioles and an active crown producing multiple female flowers. One established zucchini fruit is enlarging evenly with firm texture and healthy coloration. Overall structure is upright and stable, with no visible signs of disease, rot, or stress.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Early Seedling Through First Fruit Set
Productive Vertical Growth (New Fruit And Stem Climbing)

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 60°F overnight. Wind gusts as high as 28 mph.
journal.observations: The plant remains vigorous and upright with a broad, healthy canopy and strong petioles. Multiple buds and developing fruit structures are present near the crown, and one lower zucchini fruit is reported as soft and mushy, consistent with an aborted/failed set. Lower foliage is close to the soil line and ready for selective removal to support vertical training and airflow.
journal.actions: Remove the soft/mushy zucchini fruit by cutting the stem cleanly 1 inch above the attachment point. Prune 1–2 lowest leaves that are closest to the soil to improve airflow and keep foliage off the soil surface. Provide a deep, slow watering using a hose trickle for 2 minutes, pause 2 minutes, then repeat another 2 minutes, keeping water off foliage and the crown.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow morning after watering to confirm moisture recovery and verify whether pH normalizes with better soil contact. Continue monitoring new female buds and plan morning hand-pollination when blooms open. Keep developing fruits elevated and dry, and maintain a clean, airy crown as vertical training continues.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the soft/mushy lower zucchini should be removed; confirmed it should be cut off cleanly to prevent rot and pest attraction. Reviewed pruning of bottom leaves for vertical training and confirmed selective removal of 1–2 lowest leaves is appropriate. Interpreted the high pH reading as possibly skewed by dry soil and recommended rechecking after deep watering.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the zucchini showing a wide, healthy canopy with strong leaf structure and minor leaf-edge damage consistent with chewing.
Low-angle view of a developing zucchini fruit with the spent blossom attached, positioned near the plant base.
Crown and lower stem area showing vertical training tie placement and multiple fruit/bud structures developing near the main stem.
photos.tags: zucchini, crown, stem, vertical-training, buds, fruiting

photos.caption: Close view of the main stem with multiple nodes and developing buds, showing thick, healthy structure and good airflow potential after lower leaf removal.
photos.tags: zucchini, stem, nodes, buds, structure, airflow

photos.caption: Interior crown view showing several developing buds at different stages clustered near the growth point.
Soil surface view beneath the canopy showing exposed soil and spacing around the plant base prior to watering.
Lower leaf on the soil surface showing mild yellowing and wear, indicating a good candidate for removal during vertical training cleanup.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant appears vigorous and upright with healthy green foliage and strong, turgid petioles. A white, webby patch of fungal-looking growth is present on the soil surface and remains visible into mid-afternoon, consistent with active decomposition in organic-rich soil. Multiple female flowers and developing fruits are visible, and at least one previously pollinated fruit appears to be elongating and darkening, consistent with early successful set. The crown and lower stem area appear structurally sound with no obvious collapse or wet rot visible in the provided photos.
journal.actions: Do not water until the next probe reading. Leave the white soil mycelium in place (no treatment needed); optionally lightly rake the surface only if you want it less visible. Maintain vertical training with gentle ties and keep any leaves from resting directly on the soil when possible to reduce rot and splash risk.
journal.next_steps: Over the next 24–36 hours, watch the pollinated fruit for steady daily lengthening and firm texture; this is the clearest confirmation of a successful set. Continue monitoring for new female buds at the crown and plan hand-pollination in the morning when blooms are fully open. Maintain airflow around the crown and avoid overwatering while fruit is setting.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Reviewed whether the white growth on the soil surface is harmful; it appears consistent with saprophytic fungal mycelium associated with organic decomposition rather than a plant disease. Evaluated whether the previously pollinated fruit is setting; visible elongation and darkening are consistent with a successful set. Confirmed the plant has additional female flowers/buds developing and that morning pollination is the preferred timing. Confirmed the full photo set can be reviewed without inventing details.
follow_up: [2:30 PM] Observed widespread leaf drooping and folding from inside the house. Applied a slow, steady watering for approximately one minute using the hose. Leaves visibly perked back up within about 30 minutes, indicating effective rehydration without overwatering.

photos.caption: Soil surface showing a distinct white, webby patch consistent with fungal mycelium on organic material.
Close-up view of the same white, webby growth across the soil surface showing a more detailed texture.
Overhead view of the plant showing a healthy canopy and multiple blossoms within the leaf canopy.
Leaf close-up showing surface texture and coloration in diffuse outdoor light.
Leaf close-up showing overall leaf shape, vein structure, and surface condition.
Close-up of a leaf and nearby bloom area showing foliage condition and the presence of blossoms in the plant canopy.
Open yellow squash blossom showing internal floral structures in clear focus.
Developing fruit attached behind the blossom, showing early elongation and healthy green skin.
Top-down view of an open blossom framed by leaves, showing flower condition and orientation within the canopy.
Side view of a developing fruit at the base of a flower with stem and petioles visible nearby.
Crown-area view showing multiple buds at different stages clustered near the center growth point.
Macro-style image of the flower center showing pollen-bearing structures in close detail.
Close-up of a removed flower part held in hand, showing the structure used during hand-pollination.
Second macro-style image of the flower center showing pollen structures from a slightly different angle.
Close-up view into the crown showing clustered developing buds and the tight central growth zone.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny earlier with a high near 84°F; evening is partly cloudy with overnight lows around 61°F.
journal.observations: Lower leaf petioles are encroaching into adjacent green bean space. Prior leaf miner damage required earlier partial petiole removals, leaving small inactive nubs near the stem. Plant structure remains vigorous with strong crown development and multiple active growth points.
journal.actions: Reviewed selective pruning strategy for vertical training. Confirmed that one encroaching lower petiole can be removed safely, and that up to one additional lower petiole may be removed to create a clean 1.5–2 inch stem section for tying. Confirmed that old, dead petiole nubs from prior leaf miner damage may be trimmed flush without harming the plant.
journal.next_steps: Carefully trim dead petiole nubs flush with the stem without shaving or gouging living tissue. Allow cuts to air-dry before tying. Proceed slowly and limit cleanup to inactive tissue only. Additional photos and timestamp to be logged after cleanup is complete.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether an encroaching leaf petiole could be removed and whether removing two lower petioles would support vertical training. Guidance confirmed both actions are safe at this stage. User also asked if remaining petiole nubs from earlier leaf miner pruning could now be cleaned flush; guidance confirmed this is appropriate if tissue is dead and inactive.
follow_up: Await post-cleanup photos and timestamp for final structural confirmation and log update.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing lower zucchini leaves extending laterally toward neighboring green bean plants.
Side view of zucchini stem and lower petioles illustrating potential tie-in zone for vertical training.
Close-up of crown area showing prior petiole removal points and remaining inactive nubs from earlier leaf miner damage.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 67°F overnight. A 20% chance of precipitation today.
journal.observations: The plant is vigorous and actively fruiting with a wide, healthy canopy and multiple female flowers. One early fruit showed blossom-end yellowing after morning rainfall and progressed to brown, sunken tissue consistent with irreversible blossom-end tissue collapse before being removed.
journal.actions: Keep developing fruits elevated off wet mulch or soil using a dry barrier. Do not water today because soil moisture is sufficient after rain.
journal.next_steps: Monitor the next developing fruits for firm, uniform color at the blossom end, especially after rainy mornings. Recheck moisture tomorrow morning and only water if moisture drops noticeably and the surface is drying.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether a blossom would close; confirmed zucchini flowers typically collapse by midday even after successful pollination. Reviewed whether the first fruit should be kept; confirmed the blossom end showed true tissue collapse and removal was appropriate, and explained how to distinguish early stress from rot in the future.
follow_up: [3:15 PM] Removed the first developing zucchini after the blossom end appeared brown, sunken, and leathery, consistent with irreversible rot.

photos.caption: Close-up view of a developing zucchini resting on mulch, showing early yellowing near the blossom end and direct contact with damp organic material.
Overhead view of the plant showing a broad, healthy canopy with strong leaf expansion and good overall vigor.
Crown-level view showing thick petioles and active growth with developing female structures near the center of the plant.
Developing female flower with a swelling ovary, indicating active fruit set.
Low-angle view showing fruit position relative to mulch and the base of the plant, highlighting the importance of keeping fruit dry and off the ground.
Side view of a developing fruit and blossom with petals beginning to wilt, consistent with normal post-bloom behavior.
Close-up of the crown showing multiple developing buds and vigorous new growth emerging from the center.
Removed zucchini showing brown, sunken blossom-end tissue consistent with irreversible rot/tissue collapse.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 79°F dropping to around 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant remains upright and vigorous with a clean, open crown and multiple mature flower structures present. A primary female bud opened late in the afternoon following a cool, cloudy morning, allowing for successful hand pollination using two male flowers. Overall canopy posture is stable with no visible signs of wilt, rot, or disease.
journal.actions: No additional watering or fertilization planned for the remainder of the day following light corrective irrigation. Avoid wetting developing fruit and flowers.
journal.next_steps: Check soil moisture tomorrow morning after overnight conditions and any rainfall. Monitor the newly pollinated ovary for firmness and growth over the next 24–48 hours. Avoid overhead watering and unnecessary handling.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed delayed female flower opening due to cool, cloudy morning conditions and confirmed late-day opening was still viable for pollination. Reviewed handling and storage of cut male flowers to preserve pollen. Confirmed gentle handling did not damage the female flower. Discussed interpreting zero moisture readings caused by surface crusting and confirmed that light corrective watering was appropriate after afternoon dry-down.
follow_up: [11:45 AM] Removed three leaves showing leaf miner tunneling, including one fully senesced brown leaf, by cutting each petiole cleanly at the base to improve airflow and remove nonfunctional tissue.
[11:50 AM] Adjusted the plant tie after leaf removal, lowering and loosening it to improve crown spacing, reduce petiole pressure, and better support the upright stem as fruit weight increases.
[3:45 PM] Hand-pollinated a late-opening female zucchini flower using pollen from two male flowers after the petals loosened, ensuring full stigma contact to maximize fruit set.
[5:08 PM] Applied a light corrective watering (approximately 1 quart) slowly around the root zone to relieve late-day surface dryness while avoiding direct wetting of the developing fruit.

photos.caption: Close view of an open zucchini blossom near the crown, showing strong floral structure and healthy surrounding foliage.
Overhead crown view showing multiple developing buds and upright petioles, with overall structure remaining open and stable.
Side view highlighting a mature female bud with a swollen ovary prior to opening.
photos.tags: zucchini, female flower, bud, ovary, pre-bloom

photos.caption: Crown-angle view showing a spent or closing blossom near the plant center with additional buds staged nearby.
Close-up of a zucchini leaf showing classic leaf miner tunneling patterns across otherwise healthy green tissue.
Older zucchini leaf with extensive leaf miner damage and areas of tissue collapse prior to removal.
Overhead view of a remaining healthy zucchini leaf showing light miner trails but strong structure and color.
Low-angle view of the zucchini stem base after tie adjustment, showing improved clearance around the crown and proper support placement below the growth flare.
Close-up of the crown area after tie repositioning, showing relaxed petioles, no compression, and clear airflow around developing buds.
Side view showing improved plant balance and fruit clearance following petiole removal and tie adjustment.
Female zucchini flower just before hand pollination, showing a slight natural opening and a firm, healthy ovary.
Freshly cut male zucchini flower with visible, viable pollen prepared for hand pollination.
Hand pollination in progress, with the male anther making direct contact with the female stigma.
Female zucchini flower immediately after hand pollination, with petals beginning to relax and close naturally.
Side view of the pollinated zucchini ovary after completion of hand pollination, showing intact structure and good fruit orientation.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant is in active sustained fruiting with four visible female fruits forming at the crown. One established zucchini continues to enlarge evenly with firm texture and healthy color. Petioles are thick and upright, and the canopy remains open with good airflow. No signs of stress, rot, or disease are present.
journal.actions: No additional watering today following thorough irrigation. Keep mulch in place beneath developing fruits. Do not fertilize today.
journal.next_steps: Check female flowers at first light each morning over the next 1–2 days and hand pollinate immediately when petals open. Monitor soil moisture closely during this pollination window and prepare for initial vertical training as fruit weight increases.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed rapid fruit growth and timing for hand pollination, confirming that the largest female flower is likely to open within 12–36 hours and should be pollinated the morning it opens.
follow_up: [12:35 PM] Thoroughly watered the bed after initial dry probe readings to restore proper soil moisture.
[6:25 PM] Adjusted the training tie to sit between the soil line and the developing zucchini so only the main stem is inside the loop, leaving fruit and leaf stalks completely free.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing full canopy spread and active fruiting center.
Close-up of the crown showing multiple female flowers forming simultaneously.
Side view highlighting developing female buds with firm ovaries.
Existing zucchini fruit showing continued elongation and healthy coloration.
Interior crown view showing dense but well-spaced reproductive growth.
Close-up of the base showing the training tie positioned low on the main stem with surrounding growth left free.
Alternate angle confirming the tie sits below the fruit attachment without trapping any petioles.
Detailed view of the crown area above the tie showing free movement of leaves, flowers, and fruit.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant is actively producing multiple new female flowers at the crown, each with clearly defined ovaries. One existing zucchini fruit continues to elongate evenly with firm texture and healthy color. Stems and petioles remain thick and upright, and canopy spacing is open with no signs of disease or stress.
journal.actions: Apply a deep, slow watering at the base to restore moisture into the mid-range. Keep mulch in place beneath all developing fruits. Do not fertilize today.
journal.next_steps: Check female flowers each morning over the next 1–2 days for opening and hand pollinate immediately when petals open. Monitor soil moisture closely during this pollination window and prepare for the first vertical tie as fruit weight increases.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed how to determine when a female flower is ready to open for hand pollination, confirming that buds typically open once the ovary reaches about 1.5–2 inches and the petals appear puffy and loosened. Confirmed that the largest bud is very close and likely to open within 24–48 hours.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing full canopy spread and active fruiting center.
Close-up of the crown showing multiple forming female flowers with visible ovaries.
Side view highlighting developing female buds and strong petiole structure.
Existing zucchini fruit showing continued elongation and uniform color.
Low-angle view showing fruit position above mulch and clean soil surface.
Developing female flower with swollen ovary nearing bloom stage.
Crown detail showing tight bud clusters and healthy new growth.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant is actively producing new female flower buds at the crown, each with a clearly formed ovary. The first zucchini fruit continues to elongate with uniform color and a firm stem connection. Canopy structure remains open and vigorous, and stems are thick and upright with no signs of stress or disease.
journal.actions: Do not water today as soil moisture is ideal and rain is expected. Leave fresh mulch in place beneath the developing fruit to maintain airflow and prevent soil contact. Do not fertilize today.
journal.next_steps: Check female flowers each morning over the next 1–3 days for opening and perform hand pollination immediately when petals open. Continue monitoring moisture after rainfall and prepare for early vertical training as the stem elongates.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed when female flowers become ready for hand pollination and confirmed that pollination should occur the morning the flower opens, typically within 24–72 hours based on current bud development.
follow_up: [1:30 PM] Added fresh mulch beneath the first developing zucchini fruit to improve airflow and reduce soil contact during rainy conditions.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing the full canopy and active crown development.
Close-up of the crown showing multiple forming female buds with visible ovaries.
Side view of the first developing zucchini fruit resting above mulch support.
Close view of a female flower bud showing a swollen ovary prior to opening.
Developing zucchini fruit showing firm texture and even coloration.
Lower stem area showing clean structure and stable soil conditions.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant is actively growing with a well-spread canopy and healthy leaf structure. New blossoms are visible, and the fruit is elongating nicely, with healthy skin coloration. No signs of disease or rot. The crown is vibrant with new growth and multiple male blossoms.
journal.actions: Remove spent blossoms from the soil surface to reduce moisture retention and insect attraction. No watering needed today. Continue supporting the developing fruit with light mulch until upgraded support is needed. No fertilizer required today.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture tomorrow morning and upgrade fruit support in 1–2 days. Watch for emerging female blossoms and confirm pruning stub continues to dry and seal. Continue monitoring the plant's growth as it prepares for vertical training.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether low overnight temperatures in the low 50s were concerning; confirmed these are safe for zucchini. Confirmed presence of early female buds forming within the crown.
follow_up: [7:42 AM] Confirmed the leaf was cut correctly at the proper petiole position.
[8:02 AM] Added a small layer of mulch beneath the developing fruit for gentle support.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing male blossoms and a widening canopy.
Close view of the crown showing the clean pruning cut and active new growth.
Side view of the developing zucchini fruit positioned above the soil surface.
Developing zucchini fruit showing healthy elongation and firm color.
Spent male blossoms removed from the soil surface to reduce moisture trapping.
Interior crown view showing multiple forming female buds.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 73°F dropping to 53°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows strong overall growth with vigorous new leaves emerging from the crown and multiple male blossoms opening today. The first developing fruit continues to elongate with healthy skin coloration and no signs of rot. The pruning cut from earlier has dried cleanly and shows normal healing. Soil surface remains dry despite light showers, consistent with improved but still quick-draining bed conditions.
journal.actions: Remove spent blossoms from soil surface to reduce moisture retention and insect attraction. No watering is needed this evening. Continue supporting the developing fruit with light mulch until upgraded support is needed. No fertilizer required today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning and upgrade fruit support in 1–2 days as it lengthens. Monitor crown for additional female buds and confirm pruning stub continues to dry and seal. Watch overnight temperatures, though current forecast remains safe for growth.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether low overnight temperatures in the low 50s were concerning; confirmed these are safe for zucchini. Confirmed presence of early female buds forming within the crown. Clarified that the pruning cut was correct and that adding a light mulch pad under the developing fruit was acceptable.
follow_up: [7:42 AM] Confirmed the leaf was cut correctly at the proper petiole position.
[8:02 AM] Added a small layer of mulch beneath the developing fruit for gentle support.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing male blossoms and a widening canopy.
Close view of the crown showing the clean pruning cut and active new growth.
Side view of the developing zucchini fruit positioned above the soil surface.
Developing zucchini fruit showing healthy elongation and firm color.
Spent male blossoms removed from the soil surface to reduce moisture trapping.
Interior crown view showing multiple forming female buds.
Healing pruning cut drying cleanly with no moisture pooling.
Healthy fruit-to-stem junction showing no rot or lesions.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows vigorous early fruit development with noticeable length gain and firm, bright green skin. Multiple new blossoms are forming at the crown and overall canopy growth has expanded since yesterday. The soil appears more open and workable after removing much of the compacted topsoil and sand layer, improving aeration and probe access. One large lower leaf shows advanced senescence with yellow mottling and necrotic spotting, but newer foliage remains bright and healthy. Moisture is moderately low this morning and light rain began shortly after the probe reading.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today as rainfall is expected to replenish soil moisture. Leave the senescing lower leaf in place until conditions are dry enough to remove it cleanly. Avoid disturbing the crown or new blossoms and allow the soil to settle after loosening.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning after rain to confirm even hydration. Plan to remove the aging lower leaf once the leaf surface is dry. Monitor the developing fruit for continued swelling and watch the crown for emerging female blossoms. Prepare for the first vertical tie within the next several days as the stem continues to elongate.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed postponing leaf removal due to rain beginning immediately after the reading, confirming that waiting until dry conditions is the correct approach.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing vigorous canopy growth and developing blossoms after soil loosening.
Close-up of the enlarging zucchini fruit with firm, bright green skin and a dried blossom end.
Crown area with multiple new buds forming and healthy emerging foliage.
Lower leaf displaying advanced natural senescence with yellow mottling and necrotic spotting.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The developing zucchini fruit shows clear length gain with firm, evenly green skin and a clean attachment point, indicating healthy early fruit development. The crown is active with multiple new blooms forming, and overall foliage remains bright and vigorous. One large lower leaf displays pronounced mottling and yellow webbing typical of natural senescence, while newer leaves remain unaffected. Soil moisture is in an ideal mid-range and no signs of stress or pests are visible.
journal.actions: Do not water at this time as moisture is ideal and rain is expected later today. Leave the heavily mottled lower leaf attached for now. Maintain full sun exposure and avoid pruning or fertilizing today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning, especially if rainfall is light or scattered. Plan to remove the senescing lower leaf later in the week during dry conditions. Monitor the swelling fruit for continued growth and watch new female buds for upcoming pollination opportunities.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the mottled leaf indicated a problem; confirmed it reflects natural aging and is not disease-related.

photos.caption: Close-up of the developing zucchini fruit showing clear early swelling and a drying blossom end.
Overhead view of the crown with multiple blossoms and vigorous new growth.
Side view showing full canopy and healthy leaf structure.
Image of the large mottled lower leaf exhibiting natural age-related yellowing.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high near 86°F, patchy fog early. Night partly cloudy with a low around 66°F. Next day mostly sunny near 87°F with a slight chance of afternoon showers.
journal.observations: Soil surface and upper profile were extremely dry at midday, leading to essentially zero moisture readings from the probe. The plant began to look thirsty in the heat, but the pollinated baby zucchini showed clear enlargement compared with previous days, remaining firm and evenly green. One large lower leaf showed pronounced yellow mottling typical of age or prior stress.
journal.actions: Provide a thorough, slow watering at the base of the plant to re-wet the full root zone after the bone-dry reading. Avoid wetting the foliage as much as possible.
journal.next_steps: Check soil early the next morning; water again only when the top 1-2 inches are dry while keeping the deeper root zone consistently moist. Plan to remove the heavily mottled lower leaf once there is plenty of newer foliage. Delay any additional fertilization until at least a week after the last feeding unless growth clearly slows.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the zero moisture reading meant a serious problem or just very dry surface soil, and confirmed that the baby zucchini appears to be taking and continuing to grow. Also covered how often to water under hot, sunny conditions and that consistent soil moisture is key to avoiding blossom-end rot and fruit aborting.

photos.caption: Close-up of the developing zucchini fruit with the spent blossom still attached, showing clear length gain.
Overhead view of the plant with one large heavily mottled lower leaf and otherwise healthy canopy.
Soil surface around the plant appearing very dry prior to the deep watering.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 84°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Plant shows strong vegetative growth with multiple flower buds at various stages. One well-formed female flower with a baby zucchini at the base opened early in the morning. Additional female buds are visible but not yet open. A few older leaves still show yellowing at the margins, while most foliage is deep green.
journal.actions: No irrigation needed at the time of the afternoon reading as soil moisture remained high. No additional fertilizer applied after the previous day's light feeding.
journal.next_steps: Watch the pollinated fruit over the next several days for steady enlargement and firm, bright green skin. Remove any fully necrotic leaves later in the week once the plant has plenty of newer foliage.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Walked step-by-step through hand pollination using a male flower from a neighboring plant, including how to pick the male flower, strip the petals, and gently brush the anther onto the female stigma. Also discussed whether a developing fruit without a visible flower would continue to grow (it will only if it was successfully pollinated).
follow_up: [7:05 AM] Hand-pollinated the first open female flower using a freshly picked male flower from the neighboring zucchini plant. The stigma appeared well coated in pollen after several gentle passes.

photos.caption: Before hand pollination: open female flower with visible stigma and baby zucchini at the base.
After hand pollination: close-up showing pollen coating on the female stigma.
Photo of the used male flower with petals removed and anther exposed after pollination.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 84°F, low around 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Canopy remains full with many buds. One large older leaf shows extensive yellow mottling and necrosis, while newer leaves look strong. First small female fruits are present with blossoms still closed. Light chewing continues on some leaves.
journal.actions: Give the plant its first light organic feeding with Purived 4-5-5, applied at a reduced rate around the dripline and gently scratched into the soil surface. No additional watering was required immediately because root zone moisture was high.
journal.next_steps: Monitor for any fertilizer burn (unlikely at the reduced rate) and watch the developing female buds for opening so that hand pollination can be done if bees are scarce.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to treat leaf-chewing insects now or wait, and how to fertilize safely using the existing organic products on hand.
follow_up: [5:35 PM] Sprayed Captain Jack's Deadbug ready-to-use formulation in the evening, targeting the undersides of leaves with visible chewing while avoiding flowers as much as possible.

photos.caption: Overhead shot showing vigorous plant with one heavily mottled lower leaf.
Close-up of developing fruiting area with multiple female buds and a treated leaf.
Side view of the plant after Deadbug application with trimmed older leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 82°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: Earlier in the afternoon the surface soil was bone dry and the probe initially could not get a valid reading. The plant showed some droop in the heat before watering, but leaves perked back up afterward. A large older leaf was increasingly yellow and mottled, while the rest of the canopy remained healthy. Several female buds were forming closer to the crown.
journal.actions: Provide a deep watering after finding the surface too dry to get a valid reading, then retest once moisture had moved down. Evaluate necrotic lower foliage and plan selective removal. No pesticide applied yet.
journal.next_steps: Allow the soil to dry only to the upper 1-2 inches before the next watering, especially in hot sun. Continue to monitor older leaves and remove them once fully necrotic to improve airflow and reduce disease risk. Prepare to start light fertilization as flowering increases.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Talked through how to interpret a zero moisture reading when the probe is only hitting dry surface material versus the main root zone. Also discussed when and how to remove badly damaged leaves at the base and when to begin organic fertilization.
follow_up: [1:15 PM] Removed two clearly necrotic lower leaves by cutting the petioles close to the base with clean pruners to prevent disease spread and improve airflow.

photos.caption: Overhead view after watering showing leaves recovering from midday droop.
Close view of a large lower leaf with advanced yellowing and mottling prior to removal.
Central crown with multiple developing flower buds and emerging new foliage.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high near 84°F and wind gusts up to 19 mph, low around 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Plant remains turgid with upright petioles and expanding foliage. Several flower buds are visible near the crown, including early female buds with small swelling at the base. Light chewing present on a few leaves but overall leaf area is intact.
journal.actions: No watering required; soil moisture still adequate. No fertilizer applied yet; organic base mix and existing nutrients are supporting good vegetative growth.
journal.next_steps: Continue to monitor chewing damage and keep an eye out for squash vine borers or caterpillars. Plan a first light side-dressing of organic fertilizer within the next couple of days as flowering ramps up.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Reviewed available garden products (organic fertilizer, dolomitic lime, Captain Jack's line, etc.) and discussed using a gentle organic fertilizer such as Purived 4-5-5 when plants are in active growth. Also covered that light chewing at this stage is acceptable if growth remains strong.

photos.caption: Overhead shot of Zucchini Center showing strong foliage and emerging buds.
Close-up of developing central buds including small potential female flowers.
Leaf detail where minor chewing damage is visible along margins.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy day with temperatures in the mid-70s°F, possible showers around 6 PM, low near 69°F overnight.
journal.observations: Zucchini 002 showing a full, vigorous canopy with several large mature leaves and some older lower leaves displaying mottling and damage. New growth at the crown looks healthy and bright green. Some minor chewing visible on a few leaves but no major pest outbreak seen.
journal.actions: No fertilizer or pesticide applied today. No irrigation needed because the root zone moisture reading was still comfortably high.
journal.next_steps: Monitor the damaged lower leaves for progression and plan to remove them once clearly necrotic. Continue watching for leaf-chewing pests in the evenings.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to worry about mottled, damaged leaves and whether to remove them immediately. Decided to wait and remove only clearly necrotic leaves starting from the base, while keeping healthy foliage.

photos.caption: Overhead view of Zucchini 002 showing full canopy with one mottled lower leaf.
Close view of crown and developing flower buds at the center of the plant.
Detail of a mottled lower leaf with cosmetic damage but still attached.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The probe returned all zero values before watering, indicating it was inserted into very dry material in the newly added organic mix rather than the main hydrated soil column. The plant itself remained vigorous and fully hydrated, with upright, glossy leaves and active new serrated growth at the crown. The dryness was isolated to the surface amendment layer and not representative of the plant's root zone health.
journal.actions: Provide a thorough watering at the base and directly over the added soil mound, ensuring water penetrates the dry surface layer while keeping all leaves dry.
journal.next_steps: Allow 45-60 minutes for moisture to equilibrate through the amended soil before taking a follow-up reading. Continue monitoring the crown for expansion and check leaf posture for any signs of delayed stress.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed how long to wait before taking a follow-up probe reading after watering; advised a 45-60 minute delay for moisture redistribution.
follow_up: [4:08 PM] Follow-up reading showed fully restored probe accuracy after watering, with moisture rising to 54.00 mS/cm and pH stabilizing at 7.35. The soil amendment integrated properly once hydrated, and nutrient values increased slightly as expected. The plant showed noticeable leaf expansion and improved turgor following the soaking.

photos.caption: Overhead view of Zucchini (Center) showing vigorous canopy despite dry surface soil.
Side angle displaying leaf spread and healthy structure prior to watering.
Close view of the lower leaf area and dry organic soil added earlier.
Wide canopy view revealing uniform leaf hydration and turgor.
Detailed look at the central crown showing active new serrated leaf emergence.
Follow-up photo showing visibly larger leaves and renewed turgor after watering.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Zucchini (Center) continues to show strong vegetative growth with an upright canopy, firm stems, and active central leaf expansion. New serrated leaves are emerging consistently and leaf color remains bright green with no signs of water stress or nutrient imbalance. The lowest true leaf shows expected aging but no progression of damage. The soil amendment added earlier (organic potting mix placed under the two lowest leaves) remains visually dry on the surface, but probe measurements confirm the root zone moisture at a healthy mid-range. The initial probe reading of pH 9.25 appears to be a temporary spike from localized alkaline dust or lime particles in the new mix; the second reading of pH 7.75 is the more accurate profile for the main soil column. No signs of overwatering or stem stress are present, and the plant is well-supported at the base.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture levels are healthy and the plant shows no signs of thirst. Do not fertilize. Leave lower aging leaf attached for now. Allow the new soil amendment to settle naturally. Maintain full daylight exposure and avoid disturbing the freshly added soil.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH tomorrow to confirm the soil amendment has equilibrated. Begin considering mulch again within the next 1-2 days once the top layer fully integrates. Start planning early training once the main stem gains additional height. Monitor leaf posture for any delayed irrigation response.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water after observing the new soil appearing dry; advised that the root zone is properly hydrated based on probe readings and plant condition, so watering should be avoided today.

photos.caption: Wide view of Zucchini (Center) with fresh organic soil around the base.
Side view showing leaf spread and stable stem posture.
View of lower leaves and soil line after amendment.
Crown center showing new serrated leaf development.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: Zucchini (Center) continues its rapid vegetative boom with strong central crown development and several new serrated leaves emerging. Leaf color is bright and consistent with no signs of nutritional stress. Moisture levels are healthy and slightly elevated, indicating stable hydration without waterlogging. Older leaves show minor cosmetic chew marks but no new pest activity. Stem is thickening without signs of stress, and soil structure remains airy and supportive.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizing needed today. Allow full sun exposure. Avoid pruning, tying, or disturbing soil around the stem. Continue monitoring moisture and leaf condition.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture in 24 hours. Plan to add mulch within 1-2 days once moisture remains stable. Begin vertical training once the main stem reaches sufficient height. Watch pH and fertility trends to ensure levels remain within ideal range.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing healthy canopy expansion and leaf spread.
Wide view of Zucchini (Center) within the raised bed showing spacing and posture.
Close-up of the central crown showing new serrated leaf growth.
Side view highlighting leaf orientation and healthy stem posture.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows strong vegetative growth with expanding broad leaves and a vigorous central crown. Leaf color is uniformly green with only minor cosmetic chew marks on older leaves. The cotyledon is fading as expected. Soil moisture is optimal and the pH has risen slightly above the ideal range but not at a harmful level. No signs of new pests or fungal issues. The stem is stable following previous soil support and the canopy is increasing in diameter.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer needed today. Do not prune or tie yet. Allow full sun exposure. Avoid disturbing soil around the stem.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture in 24 hours. Consider adding mulch within 1-2 days once moisture holds steady. Begin vertical training when the stem gains additional height. Monitor pH trend and adjust only if it remains elevated for several days.

photos.caption: Top view of Zucchini (Center) showing full canopy expansion.
Side view showing the plant's posture and stem stability.
Close-up of central crown with new serrated leaf emerging.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 82-85°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant shows healthy upright growth with several expanding true leaves and light yellowing on older lower leaves touching or near the soil. Soil surface is beginning to dry. No new pest damage observed.
journal.actions: Do not remove the yellowing leaves yet. No pruning or snipping today. Monitor moisture and leaf condition. No fertilizer needed today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture within 24 hours. Plan to remove lower leaves only when fully yellow, soft, or obstructing airflow around the stem.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to snip two yellow leaves touching the soil; advised to postpone removal until they are more fully yellow or non-functional to avoid reducing photosynthetic area too early.

photos.caption: Leaf with yellowing near soil contact on Zucchini (Center).
Base of Zucchini (Center) showing lower leaves in relation to soil line.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with high of 82°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant continues to show strong upright posture with healthy leaf expansion. Central growth point is active with several new leaves emerging. Older cotyledons show normal aging but remain structurally intact. No new pest damage beyond small, older chew marks. Soil moisture is significantly lower than the prior day, and soil is slightly loose around the base before support.
journal.actions: Water lightly today (approximately 1/2 cup) directed at the base of the stem to bring moisture into a healthier mid-range. Do not fertilize today. No pruning or tying at this stage. Allow full sun as temperatures rise.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later in the afternoon as sun exposure increases. Begin considering mulch within 1-2 days once the soil is evenly hydrated to stabilize moisture. Monitor fertility and leaf color; next fertilizer window opens in 7-10 days if readings remain low.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed probe placement behind the plant to avoid roots and about removing the early tie; confirmed that moving the probe slightly and removing the tie were appropriate steps.
follow_up: [4:30 PM] Added potting soil around and under base; improved stability and no stem damage detected.

photos.caption: Zucchini (Center) canopy and new leaf formation after mild fertilizer response.
Stabilizing soil mound added around the stem base of Zucchini (Center).

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The plant is upright and healthy with strong, expanding central growth. Leaf color is bright and even with clear improvement following the previous day's fertilizer application. Older chew marks remain unchanged with no new pest activity. Stem shows early elongation and thickening, and the canopy continues to widen. Soil surface is evenly moist with no compaction.
journal.actions: No watering needed today. No fertilizer required. Allow full sun exposure as conditions warm. Do not tie or prune at this stage. No neem oil needed.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later in the day once the plant receives full sun. Prepare to mulch within 1-2 days once the central leaves fully open. Begin vertical training when the main stem reaches 6-8 inches with 6-8 mature leaves.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether pruning or tying should begin; confirmed that it is still too early to tie or prune and that the plant should first gain height and leaf count.

photos.caption: Full plant view of Zucchini (Center) in morning light showing symmetrical leaf spread.
Top canopy view highlighting vigorous central growth on Zucchini (Center).

journal.conditions: Morning sun around 66°F with clear skies and calm conditions.
journal.observations: Zucchini (Center) appears healthy and upright with early true leaves expanding and a well-defined central growth point. Leaf color is a solid green with no wilting. Minor earlier chew marks are visible but stable. Digital probe readings show slightly acidic pH, very low EC and salt, and moderate moisture, indicating low but safe fertility and an ideal opportunity for a first mild feeding.
journal.actions: Apply first mild fertilization using 10-10-10: 1/2 teaspoon diluted in 1 pint of water with approximately 1/2 pint applied around the base of the plant. No watering beyond fertilizer solution. No tying, pruning, or neem treatment today.
journal.next_steps: Monitor the plant over the next 24 hours for improved color and growth response. Avoid additional fertilizer for 10-14 days. Recheck moisture and digital readings the following day and allow full sun exposure to support vegetative growth.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether a mild 10-10-10 feeding was appropriate given low EC, low fertility, and healthy appearance; confirmed that a diluted first feeding was safe and beneficial.

photos.caption: Full plant view of Zucchini (Center) before first mild fertilization.
Side view of Zucchini (Center) showing early true leaves and stem posture.
Top-down view of central growth point on Zucchini (Center) prior to feeding.
